page.title: List of tallest buildings and structures in Liverpool

revisions.rev:
[[File:Pier Head and Commercial District, Liverpool.jpg|thumb|300px|Architectural styles vary greatly throughout the city centre which has a long history of constructing tall buildings]] This '''list of the tallest buildings and structures in Liverpool''' ranks [[skyscrapers]] and [[structures]] in [[Liverpool]], [[England]] by height (buildings in the [[Liverpool Urban Area|wider Liverpool urban area]] are listed separately within the article). The tallest building in Liverpool is currently the 40-storey [[West Tower]], which rises {{convert|140|m|ft|0}} on Liverpool's waterfront. It is also the 15th-tallest building in the United Kingdom.{{Cite web|last= |first= |coauthors= |title=Tallest High-rise Buildings in Countries: Europe: United Kingdom |url=http://www.emporis.com/en/bu/sk/st/tp/co/?id=100053 |date= |work= |publisher=Emporis |accessdate=11 October 2009}} Liverpool is a city undergoing mass regeneration and older buildings are being demolished to make way for new developments. During the mid-[[2000s (decade)|2000s]], ten [[1960s]] apartment blocks over {{convert|50|m|ft|0}} tall in the city were demolished.{{Cite web|last= |first= |coauthors= |title=Tallest buildings in Liverpool |url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/bdbsearch.php?cs=0&convert=feet&city=Liverpool&so=roofheight |date= |work= |publisher=Skyscraper news |accessdate=31 December 2009}} The history of tall buildings and structures in Liverpool began in 1911, with the completion of the [[Royal Liver Building]], which stood at 295 feet (90 metres){{Cite web|title= Royal Liver Building | publisher=skyscraper news|date=23 December 2008|url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=369 |accessdate=2009 August 2007}} and was widely reported to be [[United Kingdom|Britain]]'s first skyscraper.{{Cite web|last=Hayes |first=Andy |coauthors= |title=Birthplace of the Skyscraper? â Liverpool Architecture |url=http://www.europealacarte.co.uk/blog/2010/08/27/liverpool-architecture-royal-liver-building/ |date=28 August 2010 |work= |publisher=europealacarte.co.uk |accessdate=5 January 2011}} This period marked the pinnacle of Liverpool's economic success, when it regarded itself as the "second city" of the [[British Empire]].John Belchem (ed.), ''Liverpool 800: Culture, Character & History'', 2006, ISBN 1-84361-035-0{{cite web|title=British Vision|url=http://www.britishvision.co.uk/liverpool.html|publisher=britishvision.co.uk|accessdate=20 July 2011}} In 1965 the [[Liver Building]]'s 54-year reign as the tallest building in Liverpool came to an end, with the completion of [[Radio City Tower]]. At {{convert|120|m|ft|0}} it was originally going to be a [[ventilation shaft]] but was later converted into a [[revolving restaurant]] and then in 2000 a [[radio station]].{{Cite web|title=St John's Beacon |publisher=Liverpool Tour |year=2006 |url=http://www.liverpooltour.co.uk/st_johns_beacon_liverpool_england/ |accessdate=11 August 2009}} In 2008, Radio City Tower was topped by the [[Beetham Organization]]s' West Tower by 20 metres.{{Cite web|title=Beetham Tower West |publisher=skyscraper news |date=9 October 2008 |url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=165 |accessdate=7 August 2009}} However this record could soon be broken by the proposed [[King Edward Tower]] at 170 m,{{Cite web|title= King Edward Tower |publisher=skyscraper news |date=12 July 2007 |url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=5264 |accessdate=7 August 2009}} which would also become one of the tallest buildings in the United Kingdom outside of London upon completion.{{Cite web|last=Murphy |first=Liam |title=Liverpool could have UK's tallest building outside London |publisher=[[Liverpool Daily Post]] |date=27 July 2007 |url=http://icliverpool.icnetwork.co.uk/0100news/0100regionalnews/tm_headline=liverpool-could-have-uk-s-tallest-building-outside-london&method=full&objectid=19528922&page=1&siteid=50061-name_page.html |accessdate=7 August 2009}} There is also an ambitious proposal named [[Liverpool Waters]] which if built would include most of the city's tallest buildings, with numerous being over fifty storeys tall.{{Cite web|last= |first= |coauthors= |title=Homepage |url=http://www.liverpoolwaters.co.uk/content/home.php |date= |work= |publisher=The Peel Group |accessdate=5 January 2011}} However plans for this development so close to the main waterfront could affect the city's status as a [[World Heritage Site]] according to [[English Heritage]]. The tallest building ever envisaged for Liverpool was the Otterspool Tower at {{convert|305|m|ft|0}} and 79 storeys. However, the centrepiece for a proposed 1980s 'garden festival' was never built.{{Cite web|title=Otterspool Tower |publisher=Skyscrapernews |url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=428 |accessdate=12 July 2010}} As of 2010, the tallest building pending approval is the [[Shanghai Tower (Liverpool)|Shanghai Tower]] which will contain 60 storeys and be at least {{convert|200|m|ft|0}} tall if and when built.{{Cite web|title=Shanghai Tower |publisher=Emporis |url=http://www.emporis.com/application/?nav=building&lng=3&id=shanghaitower-liverpool-unitedkingdom |accessdate=12 July 2010}} __TOC__ {{wide image|Liverpool Skyline with HMS Ark Royal.jpg|1200px|
Panoramic view of Liverpool seen from the [[River Mersey]] in January 2009. The [[Pier Head|Three Graces]], Liverpool's two cathedrals ([[Liverpool Cathedral|Anglican]] and [[Liverpool Metropolitan Cathedral|Roman Catholic]]) and skyscrapers of the new commercial district are all visible.
}} ==Tallest buildings and structures in Liverpool== This list ranks the top 37 completed buildings and structures in [[Liverpool]] at least 45m tall, which excludes buildings under construction, proposed buildings and cancelled buildings. Cancelled projects such as the Otterspool Tower, Brunswick Quay, the Fourth Grace Towers and Lime Street Gateway are not included.{{Cite web|title=Buildings in United Kingdom > North West > Liverpool |publisher=Skyscraper news |date= |url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/bdbsearch.php?city=Liverpool&so=roofheight |accessdate=5 January 2011}} ===Under construction=== This lists buildings that are under construction in Liverpool (over 45m). {| class="wikitable sortable" ! This lists buildings that have only been proposed to be built in Liverpool (over 45m). {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Name ! Height m (ft) ! Floors ! Year
(est.) !class="unsortable"| Notes |- | align="center" | [[Shanghai Tower (Liverpool)|Shanghai Tower]] || align="center"|200+ (656+) || align="center"|60|| align="center"|2025|| align="center"| |- | align="center" | [[King Edward Tower]] || align="center"|170 (558) || align="center"|54|| align="center"|2014|| align="center"|{{Cite web|last=Unger |first=Paul |title=Liverpool displays towering ambition |publisher=propertyweek |date=13 July 2007 |url=http://www.propertyweek.com/story.asp?storycode=3091077 |accessdate=9 August 2009}}{{Cite web|last=Thompson |first=Paul|title=Peel Objects to Liverpool's King Edward |publisher=cnplus |date=8 February 2008 |url=http://www.cnplus.co.uk/news/peel-objects-to-liverpools-king-edward/639204.article |accessdate=9 August 2009}} |- | align="center" | Kings Dock Tower 1 || align="center"|67 (220) || align="center"| 22 || 09.0 align="center"|â|| align="center"|{{Cite web|title= Kings Dock Tower 1 |publisher=skyscraper news |date= 22 October 2005 |url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=3958 |accessdate=10 August 2009}}{{Cite web|title= Liverpool To Pass Judgement On Kings Dock |publisher=skyscraper news |date= 22 september 2006 |url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/news.php?ref=722 |accessdate=10 August 2009}} |- | align="center" | Kings Dock Tower 2 || align="center"|49 (161) || align="center"| 16 || 09.0 align="center"|â|| align="center"|{{Cite web|title= Kings Dock Tower 2 |publisher=skyscraper news |date=|url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=3959 |accessdate=5 December 2009}} |} ====Liverpool Waters==== [[Liverpool Waters]] is a large scale Â£5.5bn development that has been proposed by the company [[Peel Holdings]] in the [[Vauxhall, Merseyside|Vauxhall]] and dockland areas of Liverpool. The development is expected to create 21m sq ft of new commercial and residential floor space and consist of upwards of fifty buildings, with many over fifty storeys high. There is a sister project on the other side of the Mersey called [[Wirral Waters]].{{Cite web|last= |first= |coauthors= |title=Major Development Projects - Liverpool Waters |url=http://www.investmerseyside.com/displaypage.asp?page_key=21&table=majorprojects |date= |work= |publisher=investmerseyside.com |accessdate=27 January 2010}}{{Cite web|last= |first= |coauthors= |title=Liverpool Waters Homepage |url=http://www.liverpoolwaters.co.uk/content/home.php |date= |work= |publisher=The Peel Group |accessdate=5 January 2011}} At sixty storeys, the tallest of all buildings included within the proposal is named [[Shanghai Tower (Liverpool)|Shanghai Tower]] (as to pay homage to Liverpool's historical and present links to the Chinese city), it will include a five star hotel and over {{convert|1000000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of mixed use floor space.{{Cite web|last= |first= |coauthors= |title=Peel Unveil Plans for Â£4.5 Billion "Wirral Waters" Scheme |url=http://www.liverpoolwaters.co.uk/content/news.php?id=231 |date= |work= |publisher=The Peel Group |accessdate=5 January 2011}}{{Cite web|last= |first= |coauthors= |title=Â£300 Million Tower Planned for Liverpool |url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-news/regional-news/2007/07/27/300million-tower-planned-for-liverpool-64375-19528805/ |date=27 July 2007 |work= |publisher=[[Liverpool Daily Post]] |accessdate=27 January 2010}} Developers have stated that the project may take fifty years before it is finished. The proposals are presently at the planning stage and are subject to public acceptance.[http://icliverpool.icnetwork.co.uk/liverpoolecho/news/echonews/tm_headline=people-power-to-decide-fate-of-new--5-5bn-waterfront&method=full&objectid=18715809&siteid=50061-name_page.html People Power to Decide Fate of New Â£5.5 Billion Waterfront], Neil Hodgson, [[Liverpool Echo]], 7 March 2007 [[Image:liverpoolfuturebuildings.png|thumb|700px|center|The eight tallest completed, approved and proposed buildings and structures in Liverpool. Note that Shanghai Tower is the only building within the Liverpool Waters development that has been specifically proposed, many other buildings will consist of over fifty stories if built.]] ====Controversy==== Liverpool's status as a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]] has been threatened with withdrawal by [[English Heritage]]{{cite web|last=Brown|first=Jonathan|title=Threat to Liverpool's World Heritage Site|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/threat-to-liverpools-world-heritage-site-2190167.html|publisher=independent.co.uk|accessdate=30 August 2011}} if plans for [[Liverpool Waters]] goes ahead, claiming that the development would risk "overwhelming the defining characteristics of the area with opposing ones". A spokesperson for English Heritage said: "We believe that it is possible to come up with a creative and imaginative scheme of regeneration for the area without necessarily having these tall buildings [at [[Clarence Dock (Liverpool)|Clarence Dock]]] that is still economically viable and diminishes the impact."{{cite web|last=Carter|first=Helen|title=Liverpool's Heritage Status 'at Risk' from Shanghai-style Plan|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2011/may/16/liverpool-world-heritage-status-risk|publisher=Guardian.co.uk|accessdate=30 August 2011}} Development company [[The Peel Group|Peel]] however have refused the removal of any skyscrapers from the [[Liverpool Waters|Liverpool Water Project]].{{cite web|last=Bartlett|first=David|title=Liverpool Waters Scheme Could Damage World Heritage Site New Report Warns|url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-news/regional-news/2011/05/16/liverpool-waters-scheme-could-damage-world-heritage-site-new-report-warns-92534-28699451/|publisher=Liverpool Daily Post|accessdate=30 August 2011}} Later this year [2011] the proposed site will be visited by [[UNESCO]] inspectors who will advise Unescoâs World Heritage Committee whether the cityâs status, which was awarded in 2004, should go on the â[[List of World Heritage in Danger|at risk]]â register.{{cite web|last=Bartlett|first=David|title=Planning Decision on Liverpool Waters Will Be Delayed Until After Unesco Inspection|url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-news/regional-news/2011/07/25/planning-decision-on-liverpool-waters-will-be-delayed-until-after-unesco-inspection-92534-29112419/2/|publisher=liverpooldailypost.co.uk|accessdate=3 September 2011}} ==Tallest buildings and structures in the Liverpool Urban Area== [[File:The Triad, Bootle.jpg|thumb|The Triad in Bootle is the tallest building in urban Liverpool outside of the city centre]] The list below contains the tallest buildings and structures in the [[Liverpool Urban Area]]. This term is used by the [[Office for National Statistics]] (ONS) to denote the [[urban area]] around [[Liverpool]].{{cite web|title=National Statistics Online - Census 2001|url=http://www.statistics.gov.uk/census2001/liverpool_urban_area.asp|publisher=[[Office for National Statistics]]|accessdate=20 July 2011}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! |} ==Timeline of tallest buildings and structures== Liverpool's skyline has been built up mostly in the last 10 years. The [[Royal Liver Building]] held the title of tallest structure in [[Liverpool]] for 54 years until [[Radio City Tower]] was completed in 1965. Radio City Tower was finally beaten in 2008 by [[West Tower]]. {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Year tallest ! Name ! Image ! Height
{{nowrap|m (ft)}} ! Floors ! Coordinates ! class="unsortable"| Notes |- | align="center" | 1815â1868 || align="center"|[[Church of Our Lady and Saint Nicholas, Liverpool|Church of Our Lady and St. Nicholas' Tower]] || [[File:Liverpool, Pier Head church.jpg|100px]] || align="center"|53 (175) || 23.0 align="center"|N/A || align="center"|{{Coord|53.407028|-2.994853|format=dms}} || align="center"|{{Cite web|last= |first= |title= Church of Our Lady and St. Nicholas |publisher=Emporis|date=|url=http://www.emporis.com/application/?nav=building&lng=3&id=churchofourladyandstreetnicholas-liverpool-unitedkingdom |accessdate=23 February 2010}} |- | align="center" | 1868â1907 || align="center"|[[Welsh Presbyterian Church (Liverpool)|Welsh Presbyterian Church]] || [[File:Welsh Presbyterian church, Princes Road, Liverpool.jpg|100px]] || align="center"|61 (200) || 23.0 align="center"|N/A || align="center"|{{Coord|53.39379|-2.96383|format=dms}}|| align="center"|{{Cite web|last= |first= |title= Welsh Presbyterian Church |publisher=Emporis|date=|url=http://www.emporis.com/application/?nav=building&lng=3&id=welshpresbyterianchurch-liverpool-unitedkingdom |accessdate=23 February 2010}} |- | align="center" |1907â1911 || align="center"|[[Port of Liverpool Building]] ||[[File:Port of Liverpool Building Front.jpg|100px]] || align="center"|65 (213) || 20.0 align="center"|7 || align="center"|{{Coord|53|24|15|N|2|59|41|W|format=dms}} || align="center"|{{Cite web|last= |first= |title= Port of Liverpool Building |publisher=skyscraper news |date= 8 March 2009|url=http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=373 |accessdate=23 February 2010}} |- | align="center" |1911â1965 || align="center"|[[Royal Liver Building]] ||[[File:Royal Liver Building.jpg|100px]] || align="center"|90 (295) || align="center"|13|| align="center"|{{Coord|53|24|21|N|2|59|45|W|format=dms}}|| align="center"| |- | align="center" | 1965â2008 || align="center"| [[Radio City Tower]] ||[[File:St John's Beacon - Liverpool - 2005-06-27.jpg|100px]] || align="center"|120 (394)|| align="center"|N/A|| align="center"|{{Coord|53|24|23|N|2|58|55|W|format=dms}}|| align="center"|35.0 |- | align="center" |2008âpresent || align="center"|[[West Tower]] ||[[File:West Tower from ground level.jpg|100px]] ||align="center"|140 (459) || align="center"|40|| align="center"|{{Coord|53.40987|N|2.99668|W|format=dms}}|| align="center"| |} ==Gallery== File:Liverpool city centre.jpg|Liverpool city centre in late-2008 viewed from [[Liverpool Cathedral]], the financial district and historic waterfront can be seen to the left, whilst the most prominent structure to the right is [[St. John's Beacon]] File:Liverpool skyline.jpg|Liverpool's historic cityscape viewed from across the Mersey File:Liverpool city centre skyline.jpg|Liverpool's ever changing skyline can be seen most obviously in the city's new financial district ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.skyscrapernews.com/bdbsearch.php?cs=0&city=Liverpool SkyscraperNews: Liverpool] *[http://www.downing.com/commercial/showdetails.asp?recordid=72 The CapitalâDowning Information Page] *[http://www.thecapitalcarpark.co.uk/ The Capital Car Park] {{UK tallest buildings lists}} {{Liverpool B&S}} {{Liverpool related articles}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Tallest Buildings And Structures In Liverpool}} [[Category:Lists of tallest buildings in the United Kingdom|Liverpool]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Liverpool| ]] [[Category:Liverpool-related lists|Buildings]]
